verses.text: These are the inheritances that the Israelites received in the land of Canaan, which Eleazar the priest, Joshua son of Nun, and the heads of the families of the tribes of Israel distributed to them.
verses.comment: Here we see an orderly and divinely guided process for distributing God's promises. The leadership of the priest, Joshua, and elders reflects a visible authority structure, pointing to the importance of an ordered, visible leadership among God's people (see Acts 15:6).

verses.text: They inherited their land by lot, as the Lord had commanded through Moses for the nine tribes and the half-tribe.
verses.comment: The use of casting lots demonstrates trust in God's providence to direct the outcome, further reinforcing the connection between God's commands and their fulfillment in the visible assembly.

verses.text: For Moses had given the inheritance of the two and a half tribes across the Jordan. But to the Levites he gave no inheritance among them.
verses.comment: The unique role of the Levites, set apart for service to God without a land inheritance, foreshadows the appointed clergy and a spiritual inheritance. This supports the understanding of a priestly office distinct from the laity (cf. Deut. 10:8).

verses.text: Because the descendants of Joseph were two tribes, Manasseh and Ephraim, they gave no portion to the Levites in the land, except cities to live in, with their pasturelands for their livestock and their possessions.
verses.comment: The division of the tribe of Joseph into Manasseh and Ephraim fulfills Jacob’s prophecy (Genesis 48:5). The Levites’ share is spiritual, not material, evoking the New Testament understanding of a people set apart (see 1 Peter 2:9).

verses.text: Just as the Lord had commanded Moses, so the Israelites did as they divided the land.
verses.comment: Obedience to the Lord’s commands through Moses shows the authority given to Moses and Joshua, an authoritative mediation not unlike that seen with Peter in the New Testament (see Matthew 16:18-19).

verses.text: Then the people of Judah came to Joshua at Gilgal. And Caleb son of Jephunneh the Kenizzite said to him, 'You know what the Lord said to Moses the man of God about you and me at Kadesh-barnea.'
verses.comment: Caleb’s direct appeal to Joshua is based on God’s promise, showing the importance of memory and tradition in the life of faith (see Ps. 119:16).

verses.text: 'I was forty years old when Moses the servant of the Lord sent me from Kadesh-barnea to spy out the land, and I brought back news to him as it was in my heart.'
verses.comment: Caleb’s faithful witness provides an example of perseverance and truthfulness, core aspects of Christian life (cf. Hebrews 3:14).

verses.text: 'But my brothers who went up with me made the heart of the people melt with fear. I, however, wholly followed the Lord my God.'
verses.comment: Caleb’s full-hearted fidelity to God is held up as a model for all believers, reminiscent of the New Testament call to wholehearted discipleship (Luke 9:62).

verses: 'Surely the land on which your foot has walked shall be your inheritance and your children’s forever, because you have wholly followed the Lord my God.

Moses’ oath ties God’s promise to a faithful servant and his descendants, illustrating the transmission of spiritual blessing through generations—a principle stressed in apostolic tradition. Caleb's faithfulness leads to a perpetual legacy, reminiscent of New Testament teachings on spiritual inheritance (2 Timothy 2:2).

verses.text: And now, behold, the Lord has kept me alive, just as he said, these forty-five years since the Lord spoke this word to Moses, while Israel journeyed in the wilderness. And now, here I am this day, eighty-five years old.
verses.comment: God’s faithfulness preserved Caleb for decades. This preservation for a spiritual task speaks to God's ongoing fidelity to those who persevere in faith (see Hebrews 10:36).

verses.text: I am still as strong today as I was on the day Moses sent me. My strength now is as it was then, for war and for going and coming.
verses.comment: Caleb’s enduring strength is a sign of divine grace, paralleling the New Testament theme of God empowering his people for mission (cf. Philippians 4:13).

verses.text: So now give me this hill country that the Lord spoke of on that day. For you heard on that day how the Anakim were there, with great fortified cities. Perhaps the Lord will be with me, and I will drive them out just as the Lord said.
verses.comment: Caleb’s confidence is rooted in God’s promise and presence, not in his own strength. Faith acts in cooperation with divine grace—a cooperation called for in the Christian life (see James 2:22).

verses.text: Then Joshua blessed him and gave Hebron to Caleb son of Jephunneh as an inheritance.
verses.comment: Joshua’s blessing and gift of land to Caleb shows the authority to bestow spiritual inheritance, akin to the New Testament ministry of blessing and laying on of hands (see Acts 6:6).

verses.text: Therefore Hebron became the inheritance of Caleb son of Jephunneh the Kenizzite to this day, because he wholly followed the Lord, the God of Israel.
verses.comment: Caleb’s inheritance is explained as a result of his total fidelity. The lasting reward echoes Christ’s words on enduring reward for those who persevere to the end (cf. Matthew 25:21).

verses.text: Now the name of Hebron before was Kiriath-arba; Arba was the greatest man among the Anakim. And the land had rest from war.
verses.comment: A place once dominated by giants becomes a symbol of faith's victory and new peace, prefiguring the peace of God given through spiritual conquest (see Romans 16:20; John 14:27). Hebron later becomes a significant city in the kingly line and sacrificial worship.
